oai_dc:dc.dc:title: French. Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 02 g
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 02 g. Newspaper clipping: 'I am owner of the sphere...' keynote to Mrs. L. Crozier French's talk at the Carnegie Library. (incomplete). Ca. 1910?
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Scrapbooks; Clippings; Women; Politics & government;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: C.M. McClung Historical Collection, Knox County Public Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: For information on license and use fees and acquiring high-resolution image files, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8814. Please provide a brief description of the material.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "I am owner of the Sphere, Of the seven stars and the solar year, Of Caesar's hand and Plato's brain, Of Lord Christ's heart and Shakespeare's strain." This was the keynote to Mrs. L. Crozier French's brilliant and interesting talk yesterday afternoon at the Carnegie Library at 3:30 o'clock be- fore a large and representative audi- ence. The speaker was introduced with a happy speech by Mr. G. H. Baskette. "Unity and Individuality," the topic chosen by Mrs. French, was intelligent- ly and cleverly handled. The quotations taken from the theories of eminent philosophers and scientist's who have expressed their views along this line, of Time, Space, Mind, Force, Matter, Motion, Life, Law, Light, Love, Cause, Consequence, Circles, Color, Chord, were dissected and interpreted intelligentily, she also giving her own ideas along these lines. The application of her subject was taken in like manner: "The family, The Duties of Each Member;" "Mother's Liberties;" "Fathers' Privileges;" "Children's Freedom;" "What About Punishment?" "Who Is Mistress of the Kitchen?" The talk was delightfully informal, many of her hearers asking questions in regard to her subject. Her subject this afternoon at the same hour at the library will be on "Dual Forces." She will treat of the dual Sources in nature, art and literature. On Saturday afternoon at 3 o'clock Mock Congress will take place, tendered by Mrs. L. Crozier French to the club women of Nashville as an acknowledgement of the many courtesies extended to her during her visit. The Call. Notice is hereby given that on April 23, 1910, at Nashville, Tenn., will be held a national congress of women to discuss the most practical and effective means of inducing governments to give official recognition of the influence of women in human affairs by establishing a department which shall be the instrument by which this influence may be focussed and used as the most important factor in social progress. Each state is entitled to four delegates. The credential card shall contain the name and address of, the delegate with the endorsement of the wife of the governor of the state. As the delegates must be individualized (if married) it is desired that all such subscribe themselves, giving name and maiden name and a hyphen before the husband's name which latter must be spelled with a small letter. No delegate will be allowed from Utah, Wyoming, Idaho or Colorado having mired in the dirty Pool of politics. They are unfitted to associate with women of influence. (Signed) L. Crozier—french. E. Atcherson-—eakin. Ida Youngblood—adams. Minnie Henderson—beard. Lizzie Overton-—ewing. Mamie Riley—inchol: Carrie Clark - crockett Carrie Cole—edwards. Bettie Unzell—donelson. Katherine McTyeire-w(missing) Elizabeth Fry—page Nancy Rice—anderson.
